Wrong. Being that so many modern humans are the direct descendants of neanderthals, saying that neanderthals didn't evolve into humans is both technically correct and objectively untrue. Not all humans are directly descended from neanderthals, but many (if not most) humans today are the result of an evolutionary history which includes direct descent from neanderthals, and thus these humans did evolve from them.

Thee MAJOR issue with old human evolution is that not all regular living sites for men produce fossils. Given the right (or wrong) circumstances, biologic and chemical processes will degrade even bone and and teeth to e. err, nothing . Areas that fossilize well are awfully rare, albeit some areas do really well in making man into fossil, like the famed Olduvai Gorge.

Now for a long time, scientist have thought that because of lack of fossils, mankind was more or less restricted to those areas were fossils were found, evolving right there and only there, so we've been thinking East Africa was man's cradle. 

That may have been the case, but... It might as well be that Humans have made enormous evolutionary steps in areas like forests or swamp uplands (the slightly higher hills in and around river floodplains which still are popular today as dwelling areas for ppl to survive in the wild) 
These are areas where fossilizing is notoriously rare and difficult - but at same time these niches put vastly different ecological stresses on evolving species than the drier highlands in East Africa. It might even be, several species of early humans have evolved in non-fossilizing areas, gone their ways when circumstances changed, evolved further, and the old humanoid that didn't fossilize, has never been seen again, except for sudden changes in later human fossils.

So, most of us still think we came out of East Africa - but fossils from other areas are erased, so what do we really know ?  
As far I'm aware, it still unknown how and where Neanderthals evolved to the study Home Sapiens N. we know (Yup Neanders are Homo S, but one sapiens short from us, Homo double sapiens). 
It's like a burned down library of which only the doused books remain, and todays historians arent yet aware that that judge history by the books that survived, not aware that there have other books
There might innumerous chapters missing from human history, kinda like over 95% of the library. All of this points to a Pan African, instead of purely East African evolution, AND not excluding the possibility of the odd side step outside Africa (like Homo Antecessor) which might have returned , adding some smart adaptions to African Humans in a later stage

Humans picked up what became pubic lice by probably sleeping in and around abandoned gorilla nests. Earlier humans wanted the same fruit resources that other primates also wanted, and would essentially wait their turns to get at them and thereby utilize their old nests because it was convenient to do so.

Cro-magnon is the pre-ancient white person which is, unlike everyone else's case, totally anatomically identical to their modern European descendants, although ironically cro-magnon was 7-8 feet tall, more intelligent and more athletic than modern europeans. Cro-magnon migrated 12,500 years ago from within the northern polar circle into what's now Russia then into modern day Iran, from there split and one went into Europe and the other to india and china. No other race of people such as blacks descend from him. Cro-magnon does NOT come from Africa nor do many hominins. The majority of "humanity" does not come from Africa.

If you want a real genetic discovery, I submit to you that every ancient civilization can be identified by their paternal Y chromosome. These sixteen ancient civilizations are as follows... Greek Thracians L, Greek sea people T, Europeans R, Italy K, Medes Q, Siberia N, China O, Aramean F, Lydian F2, Assyrian G, Elamite H, Hebrew/Arab I & J, North African E3 M81, Egyptian E3 V12, Canaanite E3 M123, Ethiopian E3 V32. These sixteen ancient civilizations correspond to the sixteen grandsons of Noah. Neanderthals are Japhethite descendants and Denisovans are a mix of Japhethites and Cushites. (Not Semitic).. ‼️

Our developed society is suppressing the pressure of natural selection, there's billions of us that are not even close to being able to survive on our own without someone else providing our food, water, shelter and a warm place to escape the cold. In the past these pressures from natural selection would have weeded out the weak.

We're also allowing health problems to pass down to future generations, I for example have asthma and I have 3 kids and I wouldn't be surprised if I pass that defect down to one or more of them. In the past I might not have lived long enough to reproduce, I'm thankful for the advancements in science and health because without them I wouldn't have as long of a lifespan! There's dozens or probably hundreds of similar flaws we're all passing down these days in our developed existence that likely wouldn't have continued on a couple thousand years ago.

I recently tried to find the earliest bald man known. I’m going bald and noticed it’s ubiquity in all races and regions throughout the world indicating a likely early mutation in our evolution - or possibly simultaneous convergent evolution in many remote regions due to its resistance to lice. Maybe evolution plays little role since many men produce offspring before they go bald so what happens in our elderly years isn’t effected by evolution. But maybe my opinion is slanted by my modern social standards where people only date within their own age. A caveat is that older men have likely been siring offspring with much younger women for thousands of years so the answer to this conundrum still remains elusive to me. To any interested linguist: If you insist on the German pronunciation "Neandertaler": pronounce "Neander-" like "Hey flunder", and the "a" in "-tal" as you would pronounce the "a" in "far".
We do not write the "h" in modern German when refering to the hominid, only the place. The "-er" suffix signifies the hominid as well, meaning "man from Neanderthal"

no, there is no evidence of human species interbeeding - the next nearest genome is the chimpanzee and they have an extra chromosome which makes interbreeding impossible (human chromosome 2 is a combination of the chimp equivalent of chromosomes 2 + 3, aka, a 'Robertsonian translocation'). And yes various militaries have tried human-chimp interbreeding to create super-soldiers and it does not work. If Neanderthals interbred that proves they were the same species as us.
